column4: hi folks -- can someone point me to the instructions for creating .deb binary packages for ubuntu?
there's a wiki page on that issue on wiki.ubuntu.com, and the official Debian Maintainer's Guide.
is it hard?
well it's surely not easy for Linux novices, but not necessarily hard. I wouldn't package a library for starters though.
why don't you take a look yourself: https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PackagingGuide
depending on your needs, you may also download an existing source package, modify it as you like and do some repackaging.
especially backports are rather easy.
im using the pidgin fork funpidgin / carrrier and id like to help them in the packaging effort for ubuntu
have you checked http://www.getdeb.net/ too?
no-- wasnt aware of it
worth a try.
there's already a funpidgin Debian .deb, right? This might be the right thing to build upon.
its there for their initial fork - im using the latest beta called carrier
i built it from source yesterday
you could surely build a new package from the ground, but since there's also one, it seems better to use that.
http://downloads.sourceforge.net/funpidgin/funpidgin_2.4.1-0ubuntu1_i386.deb
is that possible because of a new branch (being the beta)
if its possible -- i'll tackle it
the effort depends on how different the new beta is, but especially since you're a newbie on packaging, asking the .deb maintainer for the source package could make it a lot easier for you.
sounds good to me
you'd only need to pick the existing source package and modify it such that the beta is build.
